The rage of the Coblyn had been a filter, a lens of soot that had smeared everything with malice and contempt. Now, with that filter gone, the colours were sharp enough to make his eyes ache. He saw the precise, intricate pattern of lichen on a rooftop, the way the morning light caught the dewy threads of a spiderweb slung between two telephone wires, the deep, comforting green of the rugby pitch in Ynysangharad Park. These were the details he had always cherished, the small perfections of the world he had sought to capture in his cooking. Seeing them again, untainted, felt like being given back a part of his own soul. The joy of it was so intense it was almost unbearable, shadowed as it was by the deep, cavernous guilt of what he had done while blind to it all.

As they neared the common, the beauty fell away, replaced by a grim sense of foreboding. Even from a distance, the change was palpable. The ugly, black scars of the fissures stood out against the green turf like unhealed wounds. A small, silent crowd was gathered around the crater that had been the badger sett’s entrance. The frantic energy of the previous day’s rescue effort had evaporated, leaving behind a residue of exhausted despair. Digging tools lay discarded on the ground. The pixies and other small creatures simply stood or sat, their shoulders slumped, staring at the mound of collapsed earth as if at a graveside. The air was thick with a shared, unspoken grief.

Gwyn and Mabli landed softly on the fringe of the gathering, their arrival sending a ripple of hostile awareness through the weary crowd. Conversations ceased. Heads turned. The faces that looked at them were smudged with dirt and fatigue, and their eyes held a mixture of fear, anger, and deep-seated accusation. Huw, the grizzled pixie Mabli had left in charge, took a deliberate step forward, planting his stout body between them and the rest of the group. He held a small, sturdy shovel not like a tool, but like a weapon.

"That's far enough, Mabli," he said, his voice low and gravelly. His gaze flicked to Gwyn, full of undisguised contempt. "And you can take *that* with you. We've had enough of its work for one night." A murmur of agreement went through the crowd. The air crackled with a lynch-mob tension that made Gwyn’s wings twitch with the instinct to flee. But he stood his ground, his heart hammering against his ribs. He had to face this.

Mabli stepped in front of him, her body a fierce, protective shield. "Stand down, Huw," she snapped, her commander's voice cutting through the hostility. "You don't understand what happened. This wasn't his fault."

"Not his fault?" a vole squeaked from the crowd, his whiskers trembling with indignation. "He admitted it! He broke it! We all heard him!"

"No," Gwyn said, his voice quiet but clear. He gently pushed past Mabli’s protective arm, stepping forward to face them all. He was terrified, but he knew this was a debt he had to pay himself. He met Huw's glare, then let his own gaze travel across the crowd until it found Bronwen. The great badger was sitting apart from the others, a monolithic statue of grief. She was caked in mud from her nose to the tip of her tail, her powerful digging claws worn and bloody. She wasn't looking at him. She was staring at the impassive wall of dirt that had swallowed her children, her dark eyes vacant with a sorrow so profound it seemed to suck all the light from the morning. Seeing her broke what was left of his heart.

"The vole is right," Gwyn said, his voice cracking. He addressed his words not to the hostile crowd, but to the unmoving shape of the badger. "I did this. A thing that wore my face and used my hands did this. A creature of anger and ruin. I was the doorway it used to step into our world. There is no excuse for that. It was my weakness, my foolish pride, that let it in. And your children… your home… they have paid the price for it." He bowed his head, the shame a physical weight that threatened to crush him. "I cannot say I am sorry, because the word is too small for the damage that has been done. I can only say that I am responsible."

He waited for the explosion of anger, for the shouts, for the order to be exiled. Instead, there was only a thick, heavy silence. It was Bronwen who finally broke it. She lifted her massive head, the movement slow and painful, and finally looked at him. The condemnation was gone from her eyes, replaced by an emptiness that was far worse. "The tremors stopped before dawn," she said, her voice a dead, hollow rumble. "But the last one was the worst. It brought the main chamber down completely. There is too much earth. We cannot hear them. We cannot reach them. They are gone." Her words were a statement of fact, a verdict delivered on the world. Hope was dead.

The finality of it struck Gwyn like a physical blow. He swayed, the hollow space inside him aching with a fresh, sharp grief. But then Elara's words echoed in the void. *You are a maker.* He looked at the mountain of collapsed earth, at the despairing faces of his friends and neighbours, and a new, terrifying, and utterly necessary resolve began to crystallize within him. He was a maker, and this was a thing that was broken.

"Maybe not," he said, his voice gaining a sliver of strength. He took a hesitant step toward the collapse. "When it was inside me… the Coblyn… I could feel what it did. It didn't just break things randomly. It followed the weaknesses. The faults in the rock, the hollows in the soil. It wanted to un-make things. But that means there's a pattern to the destruction. A structure. I can see it. I can feel it." He looked from the collapsed earth to Bronwen, his gaze pleading. "I can't bring back what's lost. But maybe, just maybe, I can help find a way through. Not by digging wildly, but by seeing how it was un-made, and using that to find a path to put it right."

A bitter laugh came from Huw. "You want to lead the digging? The arsonist offering to lead the bucket-brigade? Get out of here, Gwyn, before you cause any more harm." But Mabli was there, her hand on Gwyn's shoulder. She quickly and concisely told them of their journey to Elara, of the Coblyn's nature, of the ritual at the mine. She spoke of the wound, the cleansing, and the promise. Most of the crowd looked on with blank disbelief, the story too fantastical, too steeped in old lore to be credible. But Bronwen listened. When Mabli was finished, the old badger was quiet for a long time, her gaze fixed on Gwyn, searching his face, his eyes, the very posture of his soul. She was looking for the breaker, for the cold hunger he had seen in his own reflection. She did not find it. What she saw was something shattered, but something honest. Something that wanted to mend.

"There is a side tunnel," she rumbled at last, her voice stirring with the faintest ember of renewed will. "It collapsed in the last tremor, but it leads towards the nursery from the west. We gave it up as a lost cause." She heaved her great body to its feet, the movement a clear decision. She looked at Gwyn, her dark eyes holding his. "Show me," she said. It was not forgiveness. It was not acceptance. It was a challenge. A final, desperate chance to turn his making from a curse into a cure.

Gwyn took a breath, the air thin and cold in his lungs, and approached the place Bronwen had indicated. It wasn't a gaping crater like the main entrance, but a subtler violence. A whole section of the grassy bank had slumped inwards, creating a concave wall of packed soil, severed roots, and fractured shale. It was a dead end, a solid and final statement of defeat. To the eyes of a normal pixie, it was an impassable barrier. But Gwyn was no longer a normal pixie. He closed his eyes, shutting out the hostile stares of the crowd and the overwhelming sight of the damage. He reached for the hollow place inside him, the clean, quiet void where the Coblyn had lived. He had expected to find nothing there, but he was wrong. There was an echo. A resonance. A faint, ghostly map of the destruction, etched into his memory like a photograph’s negative. He could feel the lines of force the Coblyn had used, the vectors of its rage. It hadn't just smashed; it had pried, twisted, and exploited every pre-existing flaw with a geologist's cruel precision.

He opened his eyes and pointed, not at the centre of the collapse, but to a spot a few feet to the left, where a thick, gnarled root of an old hawthorn protruded from the earth. "Here," he said, his voice quiet but sure. "Don't dig straight in. The pressure is all wrong. It will just collapse again. You have to go under this root. The Coblyn tried to shear it, but it held. It created a lintel. The earth beneath it is… bruised, but not broken." His words sounded like nonsense, the arcane ramblings of a madman. Huw snorted in derision, his shovel held tight. "Under the root? That's solid clay, you fool. The collapse is *there*," he jabbed his shovel towards the centre of the slump. But Bronwen did not hesitate. With a low grunt that was part growl, part prayer, she moved to the spot Gwyn had indicated. Her great, bloodied claws, each one a formidable spade, began to tear at the earth beneath the hawthorn root. The soil was dense, as Huw had predicted, but after a few powerful scrapes, it began to crumble, falling away more easily than the solid wall it appeared to be.

A grim, silent accord was reached. Spurred by the badger's desperate action, a few of the other pixies, including a reluctant Huw, grabbed their tools and joined in. Mabli was the engine of the operation, her voice sharp and practical, directing the removal of the loosened earth, organising a chain to carry away the spoil. She created order from the chaos of their despair, her focus absolute. She did not look at Gwyn again, but he knew her trust was the only thing holding this fragile coalition together. He did not join the digging. His body was a wreck, his muscles trembling with a fatigue that went bone-deep. His role was different, and far more draining. He stood back, his eyes half-closed, acting as a living compass for their descent into the broken earth. The ghost-map in his mind pulsed and shifted. He could feel the pathways of destruction, the "un-making," as a network of cold lines in his awareness. Following them was a nauseating exercise, like tracing the path of a disease through a living body.

"Stop," he called out, his voice sharp with strain. "There's a slate bed, two feet down. It’s shattered. Don't put any weight on it." They obeyed, their movements more hesitant now, a grudging respect beginning to battle with their suspicion. Under his guidance, they stopped digging down and began to tunnel horizontally, shoring up the passage with salvaged planks and roots as they went. For Gwyn, it was a strange and terrible kind of creation. He was using the memory of the breaker's craft to build a path of hope. With every correct instruction, with every yard of tunnel they gained, a part of him felt a sick, vicarious echo of the Coblyn’s triumphant satisfaction, a phantom pleasure in the accuracy of its work. He had to constantly fight it down, anchoring himself to the memory of the clean water at the mine, the scent of the unfurling fern, the solid warmth of Mabli’s trust. It was an act of excruciating penance, using the language of his violator to spell out a message of salvation.

They worked for what felt like an eternity, the sun climbing higher in the sky, beating down on their labouring backs. The silence of the tunnel was punctuated only by the scrape and scrabble of their digging and the ragged sound of their breathing. Then, Bronwen, who was at the head of the tunnel, went still. She backed out of the narrow space, her great body moving with a careful reverence. "The air has changed," she rumbled, her nostrils twitching. "It is stale. It is warm." A wave of frantic, electric hope surged through the assembled rescuers. Gwyn felt it too, but as a deeper, more certain knowledge. The cold lines of the ghost-map converged just ahead, circling a small, hollow void. A pocket of survival. "She's right," he breathed, taking a shaky step forward. "It's a small space. The main collapse must have created a sealed chamber. Go carefully. The roof is nothing but compressed soil and roots."

Bronwen needed no more encouragement. She plunged back into the tunnel, her claws working now with a frantic but controlled delicacy. The others cleared the earth behind her as fast as they could. There was a final, desperate scrabbling, a muffled tearing sound, and then a cascade of loose dirt fell away into a dark space beyond. A faint, high-pitched whimpering, as thin and fragile as spun glass, drifted out of the darkness. It was the most beautiful sound any of them had ever heard. The crowd let out a collective, shuddering gasp of relief. Tears flowed freely, washing clean trails down mud-caked faces. Without a word, Bronwen squeezed her huge frame through the newly opened hole and disappeared into the darkness. They heard her make a low, chuffing sound, a noise of pure, undiluted love, followed by the louder, more confident squeaks of her cubs responding to their mother’s presence.

Gwyn’s strength left him all at once. His legs buckled, and Mabli was there to catch him before he hit the ground. The ghost-map in his mind dissolved, its purpose served, leaving behind only the deep, echoing quiet of his own soul. He had paid the first instalment on his debt. After a few moments, Bronwen backed out of the hole, her massive head re-emerging into the sunlight. Her face was no longer a mask of grief or emptiness. It was the face of a mother, fierce and tender and alive. Her gaze swept over the exhausted, tear-streaked crowd of rescuers, and then it settled on Gwyn. She looked at the filthy, trembling pixie for a long, silent moment. The gaze held no condemnation, and not quite forgiveness, but something far more profound. It was acknowledgement. It was the recognition of a debt paid, of a circle, however horribly, being closed. She gave a single, slow nod—a gesture of respect from one survivor to another—then turned and vanished back into the earth to tend to her children.

The crowd did not erupt in cheers. The moment was too fragile, too sacred for such a loud release. Instead, a collective sigh went through the assembled creatures, a sound of tension unwinding after being stretched to its breaking point. The pixies who had looked at Gwyn with murder in their eyes now could not meet his gaze, their expressions a mixture of shame and awe. They busied themselves with gathering their tools, their movements suddenly clumsy and uncertain. They had been prepared to condemn a monster and had instead witnessed a broken man perform a miracle. The sheer, cognitive dissonance of it left them with nothing to say.

Huw was the last to move. The grizzled pixie stood staring at the tunnel entrance, from which the faint, happy sounds of a reunited family were now emanating. He looked at the discarded shovel in his hands, then back at Gwyn, who was leaning so heavily on Mabli he seemed more a puppet than a living being. Huw’s face was a stony mask, impossible to read. He walked over, not to Gwyn, but to Mabli. He didn't speak, but simply held out the shovel, handle first. It was a strange, almost formal gesture. Mabli looked at him, confused. Huw grunted, and pushed the shovel into her free hand. "We'll finish shoring it up," he said gruffly, his eyes still fixed somewhere over Gwyn's shoulder. "Make sure it's safe. You… get him out of here. He needs… rest." It was the closest the stubborn old pixie could come to an apology, an admission of error couched in the practical language of work. It was an offering of peace.

Mabli nodded, accepting the truce. "Come on," she murmured to Gwyn, her voice soft but firm. "Let's go." She led him away from the common, away from the scene of his trial and his triumph. No one tried to stop them. As they left, Gwyn looked back one last time. He saw Huw directing the other pixies, his voice once again full of authority, but this time it was directed at mending, not condemning. He saw voles and shrews bringing offerings of dried berries and moss to the mouth of the sett. A community, shattered by fear, was beginning to knit itself back together. It was happening without him. The realisation was both a profound relief and a sharp, lonely pang.

Mabli didn’t take him to his own home. The handsome burl on the ancient oak by the Taff was too full of ghosts, its organised comfort a monument to the pixie he no longer was. Instead, she led him to her own residence, a far more practical affair tucked into the sturdy roots of a Scots Pine overlooking the Pontypridd bridge. There was no ivy curtain, but a simple, well-fitted door of pine bark. Inside, it was the complete antithesis of Gwyn’s home. There were no decorative flourishes, no artfully arranged acorn cups. The walls were hung with coiled ropes, meticulously drawn maps of the valley, and a large slate board covered in what looked like patrol rosters and notes on squirrel behaviour. A well-oiled collection of tiny grappling hooks and climbing pitons lay neatly on a shelf. It was a command post, a workshop, a place of function over form, and it was the safest place in the world.

She guided him to a simple wooden stool and he sank onto it, his wings drooping listlessly. He felt like a stranger in his own life, a visitor from another, more terrible world. Mabli bustled about, her movements efficient. Gwyn watched her, a dull ache in the hollow space inside him. He saw her reach for a small flask, and for a terrifying second, he thought she was going to offer him fermented blackberry cordial. He flinched, a full-body recoil from the memory of his perfect, untouched supper, the precipice from which he had fallen. The art of it, the perfection, the *anticipation*—it was all poison to him now. But Mabli's hand passed over the cordial. She took down a plain, unadorned clay cup, filled it with clean water from a cistern in the corner, and brought it to him.

He stared at the cup. It was rough, unglazed, purely functional. It was not a bluebell-head polished to a sheen. It was not part of a ritual. It was just a cup of water. He took it from her, his hands still trembling slightly. The water was cool and clean and had no story to tell. It was not a symbol of cleansing or an ingredient in a spell. It was just water. He drank, the simple act of swallowing a conscious effort. It did not fill him with resonant joy or deep satisfaction. It simply wet his dry throat. It was sustenance. Nothing more. And in its profound, artless simplicity, it was a beginning. He was no longer the maker of divine suppers, the culinary artist. He was just a tired creature, drinking water from a clay cup in his friend's home.

"Thank you," he whispered, looking at Mabli. Her face, usually a mask of sharp-edged competence, was soft with a weary, protective love. She pulled another stool close and sat opposite him, her presence a silent, solid anchor in the quiet room. "What happens now, Mabli?" he asked, the question not about the future of the valley, but about the terrifying, empty landscape inside himself. He had been defined by his obsession, his precise, sacred ritual. Without it, who was he? What was he for? Mabli was quiet for a long moment, watching him. "Now," she said finally, her voice gentle but firm, "you rest. Then, you learn to be hungry again. And we'll figure out the rest together."

Sleep, when it came, was not a refuge. It was an abyss. Gwyn did not dream of falling rocks or monstrous voices; he dreamed of nothing at all. It was a vast, silent, featureless void, a perfect vacuum where not even the ghost of a thought could survive. He fell into it not as a pixie, but as a stone, sinking through endless, textureless grey. When he woke, it was not to the gentle sounds of his oak-bough home, but to the sharp, resinous scent of pine and the low, rhythmic scrape of stone on steel. He was lying on a cot of woven pine boughs in Mabli’s home, a rough woollen blanket pulled up to his chin. The low sun of late afternoon slanted through the open doorway, illuminating dust motes dancing in the still air. Mabli sat on the floor, her back to him, methodically sharpening one of her grappling hooks. The sound was steady, repetitive, and profoundly normal. It was the sound of a world that had not ended.

He sat up, a wave of dizziness washing over him. The hollowness he felt was not just psychological; it was a physical ache in the pit of his stomach, a feeling of being fundamentally empty. The hum in his bones, the constant companion that had defined the rhythm of his days, was gone. The silence it left behind was terrifying. He looked around the small, functional space. There was no beauty here, not in the way he understood it. There was only purpose. Ropes were coiled to be thrown, maps were drawn to be followed, tools were sharpened to be used. It was a language he did not speak. His own art had been the opposite: to take purpose—sustenance—and elevate it into something beautiful and useless, a prayer against the chaos. But the chaos had come anyway, and his prayers had been the key that unlocked the door.

Mabli must have heard the rustle of the blanket. She finished a final, rasping stroke with the whetstone, tested the point with a careful thumb, and turned to look at him. Her face was scrubbed clean of mud, but etched with deep lines of fatigue. "You slept the sun around," she said, her voice matter--of-fact. "I was beginning to think I'd have to check you for woodworm." She got to her feet and rummaged in a sack in the corner, producing a small handful of something dark and wrinkled. "Here," she said, holding them out. Dried bilberries. Plump and sweet, harvested from the high slopes in late summer. A delicacy. The sight of them, the mere suggestion of their concentrated, wine-like flavour, sent a jolt of revulsion through him. He flinched back, shaking his head, a knot of nausea tightening in his stomach.

Mabli’s expression didn't soften. She didn’t coddle or cajole. She simply retracted her hand and placed the berries on the edge of the small, rough-hewn table beside his cot. "This isn't a feast, Gwyn," she said, her tone level and unyielding. "It's fuel. The machine is broken. It needs repairs." She went back to her tools, picking up a length of frayed rope and beginning the patient, methodical process of splicing in a new section. Her message was clear. She would not force him, but she would not indulge his trauma either. The world kept turning, ropes needed mending, and bodies needed fuel. He stared at the small pile of wrinkled berries, and they seemed to stare back, an accusation and a challenge. They were a piece of his old world, a world of flavour and delight, and he wanted nothing to do with it.

He must have drifted off again, for the next thing he knew a large shadow fell across the doorway, blocking the afternoon light. He sat bolt upright, his heart seizing with a phantom fear, the memory of the Coblyn’s oppressive presence. But this was a different kind of presence. Slower, heavier, more deliberate. Bronwen the badger filled the entrance, her great, shaggy form seeming to absorb the light around her. She had to duck her head to see inside. Behind her, three smaller, striped faces peeked shyly around her powerful legs, their button-black eyes wide with curiosity. Mabli put down her rope and stood, a silent gesture of respect.

Bronwen did not acknowledge the greeting. Her gaze was fixed on Gwyn. She looked at him for a long, unblinking moment, a deep, earthy intelligence in her eyes. There was no anger there, no blame, but an ancient, solemn scrutiny. "The tunnels are stable," she rumbled, her voice the sound of deep earth shifting. "The Green Man’s beard—the moss—has already begun to seal the smaller cracks on the common. The land breathes. It heals." She took a slow step forward, nudging her cubs out of the way. One of them, bolder than the others, took a hesitant step into the room and sniffed at the leg of Gwyn’s cot before its mother gave a low chuff and it scurried back to the safety of her shadow. She was showing him. This is what you saved. This is the consequence of your mending.

Then, she dropped something from her mouth onto the floor. It landed with a dull, heavy thud. It was a root. A long, gnarled, ugly thing, caked in rich, dark soil. It was a burdock root, a common, stubborn vegetable that drove its taproot deep into the ground, notoriously difficult to harvest. It was not a rare lichen, nor a perfect river-smooth pebble. It was lumpen, dirty, and profoundly ordinary. "Deep food," Bronwen said, the words a simple statement of fact. "Grows in the dark. Holds the strength of the soil. Good for cleaning the blood." She looked from the root to the untouched bilberries on the table, then back to Gwyn. The message was as clear as Elara's had been. You cannot survive on delicacies and air. Healing is not a garnish. It comes from the dark, the deep, the difficult. With a final, slow nod, she backed out of the doorway, gathered her children with another soft noise, and was gone, leaving only the dark root and its earthy scent behind.

Gwyn stared at the root. It was a piece of the wounded earth, offered not as a challenge, but as a prescription. He looked at the delicate, sweet bilberries, symbols of the life he had lost. Then he looked at the ugly, dirt-encrusted root, a symbol of a life he might, perhaps, be able to build. He reached out a trembling hand, not to the berries, but to the root. He picked it up. It was heavy, solid, real. Its texture was rough, its smell was the smell of honest soil, of worms and damp and decay and life. He held it in his lap, this offering from the deep, and felt its simple, grounding weight. After a long moment, he reached over to the table and picked up a single dried bilberry. The revulsion was still there, but it was weaker now, overshadowed by the solid presence of the root in his lap. He lifted the berry to his lips. He hesitated. Then, taking a deep breath, he placed it in his mouth and, with a conscious effort of will, began to chew. The skin was tough, the flavour muted at first, then a ghost of its former sweetness, tinged with a bitterness he had never noticed before. It was not a symphony. It was not a poem. It was food. And as he swallowed, he felt a strange, new sensation in the hollow pit of his stomach. It wasn't the joyful hum of anticipation. It was a small, quiet, insistent pang. It was hunger.

The single bilberry was a ghost on his tongue, a faint echo of a sweetness that belonged to another life. But the hunger it had woken was no ghost. It was a raw, real thing, a hollow ache that demanded to be filled. Gwyn sat for a long time, the rough, heavy burdock root resting in his lap like a sleeping animal. It was an ugly, uncompromising thing, the antithesis of everything his art had ever stood for. His old self, the pixie of pan-seared pebbles and delicate reductions, would have dismissed it as peasant food, fit only for burrowing creatures who didn't know any better. But his old self was dead, buried under a landslide of terror and shame. The pixie who sat here now held the root and understood it was a gift of profound grace.

He looked up at Mabli, who was still patiently working on her rope, her fingers moving with an ingrained, practical knowledge. "I need a knife," he said, his voice quiet. Mabli looked up, her expression unreadable. She didn't offer him his own flint knife, which he now realised must be with his abandoned supper things back in his hollowed-out home. She simply wiped her hands on her trousers, rummaged in a leather pouch on her belt, and produced a small, functional blade with a worn wooden handle and a short, sturdy steel blade. It was a tool, not a treasure. It had none of the history or personality of his own sharpened flint. It was heavy, graceless, and perfectly suited to the task at hand.

He took the knife, its unfamiliar weight feeling clumsy in his hand. He found a bucket of water by the door and began the laborious process of scrubbing the root clean. The rich, dark soil came away under his frantic scrubbing, staining the water and coating his hands in a thick film of mud. It was the same mud he had woken up covered in, the same mud he had knelt in before the mine, but this time it felt different. It was just earth. It held no malice, no memory of rage. It was simply the medium of life, the blanket from which the root had been pulled. The thought was a revelation, a small, clean window opening in a sealed room. When the root was finally clean, a pale, creamy white under its dark skin, he began to cut it. The steel blade was brutally efficient, slicing through the dense flesh with a jarring lack of ceremony. He fought a tidal wave of instinct, his hands wanting to create perfect, wafer-thin rounds, to angle the blade for an aesthetically pleasing bias cut. He forced his fingers to be clumsy, hacking the root into rough, uneven chunks. He was not creating art. He was butchering a vegetable.

Mabli, watching him from the corner of her eye, seemed to understand the internal battle. Without a word, she moved to the simple iron fire-pit in the centre of her home, used a pair of small bellows to coax the embers into a lively flame, and swung a small, soot-blackened iron pot over the fire. She filled it with water from her cistern, the sound a simple, unadorned splash. Gwyn walked over and dropped the chunks of root into the pot. They landed with a clumsy plop, sending drops of water hissing onto the hot iron. There was no poetry in it. Root. Water. Fire. He sat back down on the stool and simply watched the pot begin to steam, then bubble, then roil. The air filled with a thick, earthy scent, the smell of a winter field after a hard rain. There was no anticipation, no hum in his bones. There was only a quiet, patient waiting.

When the chunks were tender, easily pierced by the tip of Mabli’s knife, he fished them out and placed them on a simple, flat piece of slate she used as a cutting board. The steam rose from them, carrying their honest, unadorned scent. His hands moved on their own, a ghost of old habits, beginning to arrange the pieces into a swirl, a pattern. He stopped himself, his hand hovering over the slate. He looked at the rough chunks of root, then deliberately, consciously, nudged them into a simple, artless pile in the centre of the stone. Then he did something he had never done in his entire culinary life. He divided the pile in two, slid half of it onto a smaller piece of bark, and pushed it across the table toward Mabli.

She looked at the offering, then at him, a flicker of understanding in her eyes. She picked up a piece with her fingers and popped it into her mouth. She chewed thoughtfully. "Tastes like dirt," she said, though not unkindly. "Good dirt." Gwyn picked up a piece himself. The texture was soft, slightly fibrous. The flavour was intensely earthy, with a surprising, subtle sweetness in the finish. It tasted of darkness and persistence. It tasted of survival. They ate in a comfortable silence, the shared, simple meal a communion far more profound than any of his solitary, perfect suppers.

"Huw sent a runner," Mabli said finally, breaking the quiet. "He's taken what you said to heart. He's mapping every fissure on the common, setting up patrols to monitor for any new subsidence." Gwyn swallowed a mouthful of the warm root, the food a solid, comforting presence in his hollow stomach. He thought of the Coblyn’s cold, structural knowledge, the terrible, intimate understanding of how things break. "Tell him to look at the old stream beds," he said, the words coming to him with a surprising clarity. "The ones that have been dry for a generation. The ground there is loose, filled with sediment. It's where the water wants to go. It's the path of least resistance. That's how it thinks." He was no longer just a victim of the Coblyn; he was its interpreter, turning its destructive knowledge into a tool for preservation. He was repurposing his own trauma.

Mabli nodded, filing the information away. The conversation moved on to other things: a dispute between two families of squirrels over an acorn cache, a patch of riverbank that was eroding near the old bridge, the everyday business of the valley. Gwyn found himself listening, truly listening, the small, mundane problems a comforting balm against the memory of cosmic horror. As they talked, as the simple, nourishing warmth of the root spread through him, he became aware of a new sensation. It was not the high, frantic hum of anticipation he had once mistaken for joy. It was a lower, steadier frequency. A deep, quiet thrum that seemed to emanate not from his bones, but from the centre of his being. It was the feeling of a cold engine turning over, of fuel meeting flame, of a machine beginning the slow, laborious process of working again. It was not happiness. It was not peace. But it was solid. And for now, it was enough.

The days that followed fell into a quiet, spartan rhythm. Gwyn did not return to his own home; the thought of its curated perfection was still a source of a deep, shivering anxiety. He stayed with Mabli, a quiet shadow in her pragmatic world. He slept on the cot of pine boughs, woke to the scent of resin, and passed the hours engaged in tasks that were grounding in their sheer mundanity. He learned to mend torn patrol satchels with a clumsy but determined stitch, to mix the pine-pitch waterproofing for Mabli’s boots, and to sort and sharpen the flint arrowheads the patrol used for chasing off aggressive crows. The work was repetitive and required a focus that left little room for the echoing hollowness in his mind. It was a different kind of making, one born of necessity, not inspiration. There was no joy in it, but there was a quiet satisfaction in a well-mended seam or a newly sharpened point. It was the satisfaction of function, of a thing made right to do its job.

His relationship with food remained a fragile truce. Mabli, with an intuition he had never credited her with, did not press him. She would leave out simple things: a handful of hazelnuts, a strip of dried meadowsweet, a cluster of raw mushrooms. It was up to him to eat. Some days he would manage only a few bites, the act of chewing and swallowing a monumental effort against a tide of phantom revulsion. Other days, driven by the gnawing ache in his belly, he would eat with a grim determination, forcing down the fuel his body needed. He cooked only once, boiling a pot of nettles and sorrel into a bitter, iron-rich soup that he and Mabli ate straight from the pot, sipping it from their own clay cups. He did not season it. He did not garnish it. He did not arrange it. He simply heated the ingredients until they were sustenance, and in that brutal simplicity, he found a sliver of peace. The art was gone, but the alchemy remained, albeit in its most elemental form.

About a week after the incident at the mine, Mabli looked up from a large, detailed map of the valley floor spread across her table. Her face was set in its familiar, no-nonsense lines, but her eyes held a question. "I'm leading a patrol up the west ridge, towards the old sheep-fold. The shepherds have been reporting shifting ground. Huw thinks it's just the soil settling after the tremors, but I want to see for myself." She paused, her gaze steady on him. "I need another set of eyes. Your eyes." The invitation, or command, hung in the air between them. It was the first time she had asked him to leave the sanctuary of her home. The thought of it, of flying over the valley, of seeing the landscape not as a source of ingredients but as a network of potential failures, sent a spike of cold dread through him. He could feel the ghost of the Coblyn stir, a faint, cold whisper of memory.

He wanted to refuse. He wanted to retreat to the quiet, mechanical task of sharpening flints, to stay within the four walls of Mabli’s uncomplicated world. But he saw the faint, dark circles of exhaustion under her eyes, the tension in the set of her jaw. She was carrying the weight of the valley's anxieties, and she was asking him to share the load. He thought of Bronwen's offering, the "deep food" meant to give strength. Strength was not for hoarding; it was for using. He gave a slow, jerky nod. "Alright," he managed, his voice barely a whisper. The low, steady thrum inside him, the hum of function, seemed to pick up its rhythm slightly, a reluctant engine agreeing to a greater demand.

The flight was an ordeal. Every shadow on the ground looked like a fissure, every rumble of a distant lorry on the A470 sounded like the beginning of another tremor. Gwyn flew close to Mabli, his wings beating in a tight, anxious rhythm, his focus narrowed to the space directly in front of him. He forced himself not to look at the common, a swathe of wounded green below them, or towards the Graig, where the invisible scar of the mine still pulsed in his memory. Mabli led them up the steep, bracken-covered slope, the air growing thinner and cooler. They landed near a crumbling dry-stone wall that marked the boundary of an ancient sheep-fold. A handful of other patrol pixies were already there, their expressions wary as Gwyn landed beside Mabli. A silent, awkward tension settled over the group.

Mabli ignored them, all business. "What have you got?" she asked the lead pixie, a tall, rangy female named Rhian. Rhian pointed towards a section of the hillside. "The ground is soft all along here," she explained. "It's like walking on a wet sponge. The Big Folk's sheep won't go near it. And there's a spring that's started weeping from the base of the wall. It wasn't there last week." Mabli went to inspect it, pressing her boot into the turf, which gave way with a squelching sound. The other pixies followed, discussing drainage and soil composition. Gwyn, however, hung back. He closed his eyes, not reaching for the memory of the Coblyn, but allowing the landscape to impress itself upon him. He felt the weight of the hill, the pull of the water within it. He remembered what he had told Mabli. *It follows the path of least resistance.* He opened his eyes and looked not at the soft ground, but at the contour of the land itself. The whole hillside formed a shallow, almost imperceptible bowl, and the weeping spring was at its lowest point.

"It's not settling," Gwyn said, his voice cutting through the other pixies' chatter. They all turned to look at him, their faces a mixture of surprise and suspicion. "The tremors," he explained, forcing himself to speak with a confidence he did not feel, "they didn't just crack the bedrock. They shook the clay pan loose. Deeper down. It’s created a blockage. All the ground water that should drain away is backing up. The whole hillside is filling up like a basin." He pointed to the weeping spring. "That's not a new spring. That's the basin overflowing at its lowest point. If we get a heavy rain, the weight of the water will be too much. It won't be a slow subsidence. The whole slope will let go at once." A horrified silence fell over the group as they absorbed the implication. A landslide. One that would sweep down the ridge and into the cluster of Big Folk houses at the base of the hill. They had been looking for a symptom, and he had shown them the disease. Rhian looked from Gwyn's pale, earnest face to Mabli, who simply nodded, her expression grim. "Show us," Mabli commanded. "Where is the blockage?" He had found his voice again. And it was the voice of a different kind of maker. Not a maker of suppers, but a maker of warnings, a creator of maps for dangers no one else could see.

He felt their eyes on him, a weight of expectation that was almost as heavy as the hill's waterlogged soil. He was no leader, no commander like Mabli. He was a creature of quiet kitchens and solitary rituals. But the truth of the danger was a cold, hard stone in his gut, and it demanded to be spoken. He took a shaky breath, the thin mountain air doing little to steady him. He pointed down the slope, tracing an invisible line with his finger. "The blockage is there," he said, indicating a spot roughly halfway down the hill, marked by an unusually dense clump of gorse. "It's an old fault line, a natural seam. The tremors packed it with clay and silt, sealed it up like a cork in a bottle. All the water that should be seeping through the deep rock is trapped above it, turning the topsoil into a slurry."

Rhian and the other patrol members stared at the innocuous patch of gorse, their expressions clouded with doubt. It looked like any other part of the hill. "How can you possibly know that?" Rhian asked, her voice laced with the same skepticism Huw had shown. It was a fair question, one he didn't have a safe answer for. "I just… do," he said lamely. "I can feel the pressure of it. The wrongness." He could see the disbelief hardening on their faces, the fragile trust he had earned beginning to evaporate. He was asking them to undertake a massive effort based on nothing more than a bad feeling.

Mabli stepped forward, placing herself at his side. "I've seen his 'bad feelings' save a burrow full of badger cubs," she stated, her voice ringing with an authority that tolerated no argument. "We are not going to stand here debating geology while a thousand tons of mud hangs over the Big Folk's houses. We are going to dig a relief channel. From the spring, straight down the gradient, to a point below the blockage he's identified. We're going to give the water a path. Gwyn will guide the route." She turned to Rhian. "Send a runner back to the common. I want Huw and every able-bodied pixie with a shovel up here before midday. Tell them to bring every length of rope and timber they can carry." Mabli had translated his esoteric vision into a concrete plan of action, a series of commands that the patrol pixies could understand and execute. She was his anchor and his interpreter, the bridge between his haunted perceptions and the real world.

The work was brutal. When Huw arrived with reinforcements, his face a thundercloud of doubt, Mabli gave him the same unwavering stare she had given Rhian, and the old pixie, remembering the lesson at the badger sett, begrudgingly set his teams to work. They began at the weeping spring, digging a narrow but deep trench, following the path Gwyn laid out for them. He did not dig. His body was a fragile vessel, and his energy was needed for a more draining task. He walked the line of the proposed channel, his eyes closed, his senses turned inward to the groaning complaint of the land. It was a nauseating process. The ghost of the Coblyn’s consciousness, the "map" of the earth's weaknesses, was not a clear chart he could consult. It was a cacophony of stresses and strains he had to interpret, a symphony of breaking points he had to feel in his own body. Every pocket of unstable soil sent a jolt of vertigo through him; every solid shelf of rock felt like a brief, welcome respite.

He would stop the diggers, his voice strained, his face pale and slick with sweat. "No, not there. Move three feet to the east. There's a sandstone lens here. It’s solid. Follow its edge." They would look at him, then at the uniform turf, but they would obey, their trust growing with every yard of channel that did not collapse. The cost to him was immense. To use this sight was to dip his mind back into the tar pit of his trauma. He kept feeling phantom pains, echoes of the Coblyn’s rage. A sharp, stabbing agony in his wing as they dug past a place where a tree root had been violently sheared underground. A suffocating pressure in his chest as they cleared a section of heavy, waterlogged clay, the memory of the deep, angry earth pressing in on him. He had to keep stopping, leaning against the crumbling stone wall, his hand clutching the simple wooden handle of Mabli’s knife in his pocket, its solid, real texture an anchor against the flood of spectral sensations.

Mabli stayed near him the entire time, a silent, vigilant guardian. She brought him water, which he barely registered drinking. At one point, she pressed a handful of hazelnuts into his hand. "Fuel," she commanded, her voice low. "Don't make me give you an order." He ate them mechanically, the taste of ash in his mouth, his senses too consumed by the groaning of the hill to register their flavour. As the channel deepened, winding its way down the slope, the earth they were cutting through became wetter and more unstable. A few small sections of the trench wall slumped inwards, sending waves of panic through the digging crews, but the main structure held. They were close. The pressure Gwyn felt was immense, a physical weight on his shoulders, a roaring in his ears that was horribly reminiscent of the hum at the mine.

"Here," he gasped, staggering to a halt. He pointed a trembling finger at the ground just ahead of the lead diggers. "This is the point. The pressure is highest here. You have to break through." Huw and his sturdiest pixies moved forward, their shovels and picks ready. They struck the ground, and instead of the soft suck of mud, their tools met it with a hard, dull thud. It was the clay pan, packed as dense and unyielding as rock. For a heart-stopping hour, they hammered at it, their progress measured in inches, the strain showing on their faces. The air was thick with tension, the whole hillside seeming to hold its breath around them. Gwyn felt the pressure building to an unbearable peak, a silent scream in the bedrock. The hill wanted to break, to release the strain in one catastrophic burst.

Suddenly, with a sound like a great bone snapping, a pickaxe broke through. A trickle of muddy water welled up from the hole, then another. Huw yelled, "Back! Everyone back!" The diggers scrambled out of the trench as the small holes became a furious fountain. A torrent of brown water erupted from the ground, pouring into the newly dug channel. It surged down the hill, a controlled flood, following the path they had so painstakingly carved for it. The relief channel became a roaring, temporary river, carrying the pent-up weight of the water safely down the slope, away from the vulnerable houses below. Gwyn watched the water flow, and felt the pressure in his mind, the terrible, groaning tension of the hillside, finally begin to ease. The silent scream faded to a quiet sigh of relief. The land was breathing again. He had done it. He had taken the language of breaking and used it to teach the art of mending. His strength gave out completely, the world dissolving into a grey blur as he collapsed into the soft, damp turf.

He woke to the sound of running water and the feeling of a coarse blanket against his cheek. For a disorienting moment, he thought he was back at the mine, the clean stream washing away the blight. But the water-sound was lower, more controlled, and the air smelled of crushed heather and damp earth, not sulphur and despair. He pushed himself up on one elbow, his entire body a single, unified ache. He was on the lee side of the crumbling sheep-fold wall, sheltered from the wind. Someone had moved him from where he had fallen. Mabli sat a few feet away, perched on a large stone, her gaze fixed on the valley below where the relief channel, now a tamed and steady stream, continued its work. The immediate crisis was over.

A shadow fell over him, and he looked up to see Huw standing there, his shovel resting on his shoulder. The grizzled pixie’s face was unreadable, his expression a complicated mixture of exhaustion, respect, and a deep, ingrained suspicion that would not be easily dislodged. He did not look at Gwyn directly, but addressed the space just to the left of his head. "The channel is holding," he stated, his voice a low rumble. "The ground on either side is already firming up. You were right." The admission was delivered with all the warmth of a quarry stone, but it was an admission nonetheless. "It will need to be widened before the autumn rains, and shored up with slate. We'll need to know the best places to brace it." It was not a question, but an assumption of future cooperation. In the space of a single, terrible afternoon, Gwyn had gone from pariah to indispensable consultant. The promotion felt like a lead weight in his gut.

"The curves," Gwyn heard himself say, his voice a dry rasp. "Brace it on the outside of the curves, where the water's force will be strongest. And look for shelves of bedrock to anchor the braces. Don't trust the soil." The knowledge came easily, a tired reflex, the ghost-map offering up its secrets without him even having to ask. He saw the structure of the channel, the lines of force, the potential points of failure, all laid out in his mind’s eye. This new sight, he was beginning to realise, was not a tool he could simply pick up and put down. It was a permanent filter on his perception, a constant, low-level awareness of the world’s fragility. Huw grunted, a sound of grudging acknowledgement, and moved off to relay the orders, leaving Gwyn alone with Mabli and the quiet hum of his own exhaustion.

The flight back to Pontypridd was a slow, heavy procession. Gwyn’s wings felt like lead, and every beat sent a jolt of pain through his aching muscles. He flew with his eyes half-closed, but he couldn't shut out the new way he saw the world. The familiar patchwork of fields and woods was overlaid with a shimmering, invisible web of stresses and strains. He could see the deep scouring of the river against its banks, the precarious balance of a scree slope on a distant hill, the subtle subsidence in the ground beneath a row of Big Folk houses. It was like seeing the beautiful tapestry of the world and, at the same time, seeing every frayed thread and weakened knot that threatened to unravel it. The sight was a terrible burden, a constant, nagging anxiety that promised no rest.

When they finally reached the shelter of Mabli's home, Gwyn stumbled through the doorway and collapsed onto the stool, his body spent, his mind a buzzing hive of a thousand new worries. The hollow ache in his stomach was a cavern now, a demanding void. Mabli, with her usual economy of motion, went to the fire-pit. She hadn't boiled the rest of the burdock root. She had buried it in the hot embers, and now she pulled it out with a pair of wooden tongs. The ugly root was transformed. Its skin was blackened and blistered, but the flesh within, when she split it open, was soft, creamy, and fragrant, its earthy scent deepened and sweetened by the slow, dry heat. She scraped the soft interior onto the slate slab and pushed it towards him. He ate, not with grim determination this time, but with a raw, desperate need. The flavour was rich, smoky, and deeply satisfying. It was the most delicious thing he had ever tasted, not because of any art in its preparation, but because every cell in his body was crying out for the nourishment it provided. It was the taste of earned rest, of a machine being refuelled after an impossible task.

He ate until the ache in his stomach was replaced by a warm, solid feeling. The low thrum of function inside him grew stronger, steadier, a quiet engine coming up to full power. He sat in the silence, watching the last of the evening light fade from the doorway, and thought of his old home. He pictured the polished slate of his hearth, the neat rows of acorn cups, the sleeping-hammock woven from spider-silk. It felt like a memory of another pixie's life. A life of beauty and order, a life dedicated to the denial of the very chaos he now saw etched into the bones of the world. The fear of returning to it was still there, a cold knot of dread. But underneath it, a new feeling was stirring. A quiet curiosity. He had been broken in that place, his identity shattered. He needed to go back and see what, if anything, could be salvaged from the wreck.

"Mabli," he said, his voice stronger now, clearer. She looked up from the map she was annotating with notes about the new channel. "I think I need to go home." She studied his face for a long moment, her sharp eyes searching for any sign of a relapse, for the flicker of fear or the shadow of the void. She saw only a deep, weary resolve. She gave a single, crisp nod. "Alright," she said. "I'll walk with you." He shook his head. "No," he said, the word surprising him with its firmness. "This part, I think I have to do alone."

The flight from Mabli’s pragmatic pine to his own ancient oak was the longest and shortest journey of Gwyn’s life. It was a distance of a few hundred wingbeats, a familiar commute he had made thousands of times without a thought. But tonight, every beat was a conscious effort, a stroke against a current of memory and dread. He flew low over Ynysangharad Park, the familiar scent of cut grass and river water rising to meet him. He saw the Big Folk walking their dogs, their voices carrying on the still evening air, small fragments of lives lived in blissful ignorance. A part of him, the old Gwyn, yearned for that ignorance, for a world where the ground beneath your feet was simply the ground, solid and dependable. The new Gwyn, the one with the terrible sight, saw the intricate web of roots supporting the path, noted the erosion around the base of the old bandstand, and felt the subtle, deep vibration of the iron snake screaming along the valley floor, not as a familiar hum, but as a constant, grinding stress on the land.

He reached his home. The thick curtain of ivy hung just as it always had, a wall of deep, living green that muffled the roar of the weir. For his entire life, this curtain had been a symbol of sanctuary, the boundary between the chaotic outer world and his own perfect, ordered universe. Now it felt like the membrane of a wound, a fragile skin covering a place of trauma. His hand trembled as he reached out to part the leaves. The air that drifted out from within was stale, holding the ghost-scent of a week-old meal and the faint, mineral tang of cold slate. It was the smell of a tomb. He stepped across the threshold.

It was all exactly as he had left it. The acorn cups in their neat rows, the spider-silk hammock tightly furled, the polished hearth-slate, the centrepiece of his life, now just a dull, cold square of stone. And there, on a broad sycamore leaf placed carefully on a low table, was the supper. His magnificent, untouched supper. The pan-seared river-smooth pebbles, arranged in their graceful swirl. The moss reduction, congealed now into dark, lustreless dots. The rosette of thrice-whipped dandelion fluff, which had collapsed into a sad, yellowish puddle. The frost-kissed lichen, a sprinkle of grey dust on a scene of culinary devastation. It was a perfect relic of the pixie he had been: meticulous, obsessive, and fatally preoccupied with a beauty so fragile it could not survive a single night.

He stood before it, the silence of the room pressing in on him, and felt a wave of profound self-loathing. This was the altar upon which he had unknowingly sacrificed his peace. This was the offering that had beckoned the darkness. The joy he had once felt in its creation was a bitter ash in his memory. His first instinct was to destroy it, to sweep the whole pathetic mess into the fire-pit and burn it, to obliterate the evidence of his folly. But as he reached out, his hand shaking, he stopped. This meal, for all the ruin it had brought, had been an act of love. A misguided, prideful love, perhaps, but a love for the earth, for its textures and flavours. To destroy it in anger felt like a second violation, a desecration of the one good intention he had possessed.

Slowly, with a reverence that felt like a penance, he picked up the sycamore-leaf plate. The pebbles were cold and heavy, inert lumps of stone. The congealed reduction felt sticky and wrong. He carried it outside, parting the ivy curtain and stepping back into the cool night air. He didn't fly. He walked to the base of the great oak, to the place where its massive roots writhed out of the soil like the knuckles of a giant hand. He found a small hollow there, a space filled with damp, rich leaf-mould. He knelt. He did not scrape the food off the leaf with disgust. He gently coaxed it, using a twig to guide the pebbles, the sad puddle of fluff, and the dark jelly of the reduction into the hollow. He laid the wilting lichen on top. It was not a disposal. It was a burial. A returning of the ingredients to the earth from which they came. He whispered a single word into the darkness, not an apology, but a release. "Go." He covered the offering with a handful of dark soil, then another, until there was no sign of it left. He had un-made his meal, returning it from artifice to element.

When he re-entered his home, the air was clearer. The stale scent was gone, and with it, some of the oppressive weight. The room was no longer a tomb, but simply an empty space. He looked at his polished hearth-slate, the mirror-like surface that had shown him the monster's face. He ran a finger over its cool, smooth expanse. He felt no urge to light it. The magic of that ritual was broken, the spell dissolved. He moved through the room, not with his old, fussy precision, but with a new, quiet purpose. He took down the rows of acorn cups, not packing them away, but stacking them simply in a corner. He un-furled his hammock and let it hang, a soft, useful shape against the wall. He was dismantling the museum, turning it back into a home.

Finally, he picked up his foraging knife, the sliver of sharpened flint that lay beside the cold hearth. The nick in its blade, the one he had found on that terrible evening, was still there, a tiny, jagged flaw. The old Gwyn would have been compelled to spend hours grinding it down, restoring the blade to its impossible, pristine perfection. The new Gwyn ran his thumb over the imperfection. The rough edge snagged his skin, a familiar, phantom pain. It was a scar. A reminder. It was a part of the knife’s story now, and a part of his. He did not look for a whetstone to erase it. He held the flawed, beautiful, useful tool in his hand and felt the quiet, steady thrum of his own heart. The silence in the room was no longer terrifying. It was just silence. A quiet space, waiting to be filled not with the hum of anticipation, but with the steady, quiet rhythm of a life being rebuilt, one broken piece at a time.

The first morning back in his own home was the quietest of Gwyn’s life. He woke slowly, not to the familiar, joyful thrum of anticipated culinary creation, but to a profound and unnerving silence. The space where the hum in his bones used to be was a quiet ache, a phantom limb he still instinctively reached for. He lay in his hammock, the familiar spider-silk soft against his skin, and stared at the curved wooden ceiling of his home. The light filtering through the ivy curtain was soft and green, just as it had always been. The faint, damp scent of the river was the same. The home was the same. But the pixie within it was a stranger.

He swung his legs over the side of the hammock, his bare feet touching the cool, smooth floorboards. His gaze fell on the hearth. The polished slate was cold, its mirrored surface reflecting the grey morning light without warmth or promise. A week ago, the sight of it would have sent a jolt of creative energy through him. Now, it was just a piece of rock. The rituals that had defined him felt like a language he no longer spoke. The hunger that eventually nudged him to his feet was not the eager, imaginative hunger of an artist, but the dull, functional ache of an engine demanding fuel. He opened his larder. It was full of potential masterpieces: jars of dried rosehips, bags of carefully sifted acorn flour, vials of birch sap syrup. He looked at them and felt nothing but a weary sense of distance. He closed the larder door, gently but firmly.

Instead, he parted the ivy curtain and flew out into the cool, damp air. He did not go to his usual foraging spots—the sun-drenched patch of wild sorrel, the shady grove where the best mushrooms grew. Those places were tainted by the memory of his old obsessions. He flew instead to a nondescript hazel thicket downstream, a place he had always ignored as being too common, too obvious. He landed on a branch and began, with a slow, deliberate patience, to gather nuts. He did not search for the most perfect, unblemished specimens. He simply took what was there, what was offered. He found a few late-season blackberries, smaller and tarter than the ones he had so carefully fermented. He ate them straight from the bramble, their sharp, honest flavour a jolt to his senses. It was not a curated experience. It was just breakfast.

He was shelling a hazelnut on his doorstep when the ivy curtain rustled behind him. It was not the brisk, commanding entrance of Mabli. The movement was hesitant, respectful. He turned to see Rhian, the patrol pixie from the ridge, standing there, her tall frame seeming to crowd the small entrance. Her expression was awkward, her usual confidence tempered by the memory of his collapse on the hillside. She held her patrol cap in her hands, turning it over and over.

“Gwyn,” she began, her voice low. “Mabli said you were back. I hope… I mean, we’re all glad you’re… better.” The platitudes died on her lips, wholly inadequate for the situation. She cleared her throat and got to the point. “We have a problem. Huw and Mabli are both busy on the east ridge, organising the bracing for the channel. It’s the old bridge. The Big Folk’s bridge. One of the main stone piers, the one on the town side, it’s… groaning.”

Gwyn stopped shelling his nut. Groaning. He knew that sound. It was the sound of stress, of a structure complaining under a load it could no longer bear. He felt a cold knot form in his stomach. “The water patrol says the current has changed since the tremors,” Rhian continued, clearly relieved to be on the solid ground of a report. “It’s running faster, and it’s hitting the pier differently. The mortar is starting to crumble away at the base, below the waterline. Huw thinks we just need to pack it with clay, but Mabli… she said to ask you first.”

The weight of their expectation settled on his shoulders. He was their seer now, their oracle of structural failure. He looked at the half-eaten hazelnut in his hand, a simple, solid piece of the world, and wished for nothing more than to be left alone with it. But the image of the great stone bridge, the very thing that gave Pontypridd its name, groaning in protest against the indifferent force of the river, was too powerful to ignore. He slowly got to his feet. “I’ll come,” he said, and the quiet thrum of purpose, the engine turning over, stirred within him once more.

They flew to the bridge in silence. It was a handsome, triple-arched structure of grey stone, weathered by more than a century of seasons. To the Big Folk driving their cars over it, it was an immutable fact of the landscape. To Gwyn, it was now a living thing, breathing under immense and constant strain. He landed on the pier in question, a wide, flat cutwater of massive, dressed stone blocks. Rhian landed beside him, along with two other members of the water patrol. He knelt, placing his palm flat against the cold stone. The other pixies watched him, their faces a mixture of curiosity and apprehension. He closed his eyes.

He didn't need to reach for the Coblyn's memory. The new sense was part of him now, an extension of his own perception. He felt the immense, patient weight of the stone pier, its roots sunk deep into the riverbed. He felt the relentless, fluid push of the Taff, a force that never slept. And he felt the disharmony between them. The groaning Rhian had described was not a sound he heard with his ears, but a feeling, a deep, discordant vibration in the stone itself. The current, deflected by some subtle, upstream shift in the riverbed, was no longer flowing past the pier but striking it at a cruel, new angle. It was acting like a liquid file, scouring away the softer foundation stones, undermining the pier's grip on the earth. Huw's clay would be a temporary patch, a sticking-plaster on a compound fracture.

He opened his eyes. “The whole river wants to pivot on this spot,” he said, his voice flat with the certainty of the diagnosis. “The main channel has moved. Packing the base won't be enough. The river will just tear it out again. You have to change the river, not just patch the pier.” Rhian looked at him, her eyes wide. “Change the river? How?”

“You need to build a groin,” Gwyn explained, the engineering term coming to him from some forgotten snippet of observation, now imbued with a deep, practical understanding. “A wall of heavy stones, upstream, angled to deflect the main force of the current away from the pier head and back towards the centre of the arch. And the foundation here… it needs to be buttressed. Not with clay or small stones, but with the biggest, heaviest, most angular rocks you can find. You need to give it a new shoulder to lean on, something the water has to fight instead of just washing away.” He was not speaking as a chef, but as a structural engineer, a diagnostician of the earth’s aches and pains. The language was different, but the core principle was the same: understanding the nature of the materials and working with them, not against them.

Rhian stared at him, then at the river, a new, dawning comprehension on her face. She saw not just water, but a vector of force. She saw not just a stone pier, but a structure under siege. Gwyn had given her his sight. “I’ll tell Huw,” she said, her voice filled with a new respect that was deeper than what she’d shown on the hill. “He won’t like it. It’s a winter’s worth of work. But he’ll do it. You’ve given us a plan.” She paused, then added, "Thank you, Gwyn." She and the other patrol members took to the air, flying off with a new and urgent purpose, leaving Gwyn alone on the wide stone pier. He stood there for a long time, the cool wind whipping around him, the river flowing endlessly below. He picked up a loose piece of gravel from a crack in the mortar. It was grey and sharp. A year ago, he would have seen it as a potential ingredient, a source of texture, a mineral note in a complex dish. Now, he saw it for what it was: a tiny, fragmented piece of a mountain, a small soldier in the constant, grinding war between the solid world and the forces that sought to wear it away. His job, he was beginning to understand, was no longer to celebrate the world's beauty, but to help hold it together. The thought brought him no joy, but it filled the hollow space inside him with the solid, grounding weight of purpose.

The weeks that followed settled into a strange and heavy new pattern. Gwyn became a fixture of the valley's infrastructure, a living, breathing diagnostic tool. The other pixies, led by a grudgingly respectful Huw, would come to him not with greetings, but with problems. A barn roof that sagged inexplicably, a patch of woodland where the bluebells failed to bloom, a stone wall that had stood for a century and was now developing a worrying lean. Each time, Gwyn would go, place his hands on the wood or stone, or simply stand on the troubled earth, and close his eyes. He would feel the subtle wrongness, the hidden rot, the deep instability, and he would prescribe a solution, his voice distant and clinical. They learned to listen, to trust his unsettling sight, and the valley became a safer, more stable place for it. But the cost was etched into Gwyn’s face, in the permanent tension around his eyes and the way he held his shoulders, as if bracing for a constant, invisible impact.

He lived in his home, but it was no longer a sanctuary. It was a workshop where he slept. The beautiful, orderly space was a constant, quiet reminder of a life that was no longer his. He took to spending his free hours, the rare moments when he was not being consulted, sitting on his doorstep, a piece of wood in his hands and his flawed flint knife. He began to carve. Not figures or decorations, but abstract shapes. He would follow the grain of the wood, feeling for its internal stresses, its hidden knots, its secret strengths. He would cut away the weak parts, celebrate the strong, letting the wood itself dictate the final form. The resulting objects were strange and asymmetrical, some beautiful, some stark and ugly, but all of them were honest. The carving was not for joy. It was a physical manifestation of his new perception, a way to process the constant, silent screaming of a flawed and fragile world into a single, quiet, solid object he could hold in his hand.

One afternoon, Mabli found him there, his lap covered in pale wood shavings, his focus entirely on the piece of twisted hawthorn he was shaping. She stood watching him for a long moment, taking in the deep-carved lines of concentration on his face. He had lost the fussy, almost preening quality he once possessed, and in its place was a stark, weary gravity. He looked older, weathered, like a stone that had been left out in too many storms. She held out a small, leafy bundle. "I brought you something," she said. He looked up, his eyes taking a moment to focus on her, as if returning from a great distance. He took the bundle. Inside were three perfect, wild strawberries, their scent a tiny, bright spark of summer sweetness. He looked at them, then put the bundle down beside him without a word and went back to his carving.

Mabli’s patience, worn thin from weeks of watching him fade into this solemn, functional ghost of himself, finally snapped. "For the love of the Green Man, Gwyn, will you stop?" she cried, her voice sharp with a frustration born of deep affection. "You spend all day listening to the world break, and all night you sit here whittling its broken pieces. You eat like a field mouse and you look like a ghost. When was the last time you actually *enjoyed* something?" He didn't look up, his knife continuing its slow, scraping progress along the wood. "Joy is a luxury," he said, his voice flat and toneless. "It requires a certain… ignorance."

"That's rubbish," she retorted, stepping closer. "That's the Coblyn still talking, making you think its misery is the only truth. You used to find joy in everything. The colour of a beetle's wing, the taste of frost on a leaf…" "That was before," he cut in, his voice gaining a hard, bitter edge. "That was before I knew the beetle's wing was fragile enough to be torn by the wind and the leaf was growing on a branch that was rotting from the inside out. I can't un-see it, Mabli. The whole world is just a network of flaws waiting to fail. There is no art in that. There is only maintenance. Repair. Holding things together for one more day." He finally looked up at her, and the bleakness in his eyes was a physical blow. "That's my job now. I am the pixie who knows how things break. That is all I am."

Mabli stared at him, her anger draining away, replaced by a fierce, protective determination. She knelt in front of him, forcing him to meet her gaze. "You stubborn, dramatic fool," she said, her voice low and intense. "You think you're the only one who sees it? I spend my life patching up the world. I watch the river eat the bank, I see the frost crack the stone, I know the hawk is always circling. The world has *always* been a beautiful thing that is constantly falling apart. That's the deal. We live on the fault line." She jabbed a finger at his chest. "Your 'art' was never about ignorance. It was about finding the one perfect, unbroken thing in the middle of it all and holding it up for a moment. You were trying to taste the stone's strength, the moss's persistence. You were listening to the earth then, same as you are now. The only difference is, now you can hear what it's saying when it's in pain."

Her words hit him with the force of a physical shock. He looked from her fierce, earnest face to the piece of wood in his hands, its grain a map of its life, its struggles, its resilience. He had thought he was carving its flaws, but he was also carving its strengths, the way it had twisted to find the light, the way its fibres had knitted together to withstand the wind. It wasn't just a story of breakage. It was a story of survival. The same way his cooking had been. He had been so focused on the beauty of the ingredients, he hadn't realised he was also celebrating their tenacity.

A profound shift occurred within him, a realignment of his entire perception. The terrible sight was not a new sense, a curse laid upon him by the Coblyn. It was his old sense, his deepest nature, amplified to an almost unbearable degree. He had not lost his art; the scope of it had just expanded from the space of a single leaf to the entire, groaning valley. He looked at the three perfect strawberries, their colour a defiant shout of life. He picked one up. He didn't just see its beauty. He saw the strength of the plant that bore it, its roots clinging to a steep, sun-warmed bank. He saw the intricate, functional architecture of its seeds. He saw the whole, complex story of its brief, brilliant existence. He put it in his mouth. The flavour exploded on his tongue, a complex symphony of sweetness, tartness, and the faint, mineral taste of the soil that had birthed it. It was the taste of a beautiful thing that had fought to exist in a world that was falling apart. It was the most honest flavour he had ever known. A low, quiet hum started up in the centre of his chest. It was not the manic thrum of anticipation, nor the steady drone of function. It was a new sound, a chord of deep, resonant understanding. He was a maker. And he was finally beginning to understand his material.

The silence that followed Mabli’s words was not an emptiness, but a space for a new sound to be born. Gwyn looked from her fierce, loving face to the small, red jewel of the strawberry in his hand, and the world tilted on its axis, settling into a new, more honest alignment. The chasm between his old self and his new self, which had seemed so vast and unbridgeable, was revealed to be a simple fault line, a crack that was part of a larger, more complex geography. He ate the second strawberry, and then the third, not with hunger, but with a profound, quiet attention, as if he were reading a story written in the language of sugar and sunlight and struggle. The taste was no longer just sweet; it was resilient.

A slow smile, the first genuine smile he had felt in what felt like a lifetime, touched his lips. It was a small, weary thing, but it reached his eyes, and the bleakness that had lived there for so long receded like a tide going out. “You’re right,” he said, his voice quiet, marveling at the simple, revolutionary truth of it. “It’s the same job. I just have a bigger kitchen now.” Mabli’s shoulders, which had been tensed for a fight, relaxed. She returned his smile with a watery one of her own, a look of profound relief washing over her features. She had thrown a rope into the abyss, and he had, finally, taken hold.

He looked down at the half-finished carving in his lap, the piece of twisted hawthorn. He ran his thumb over a knot in the wood, a place where the tree had healed around an old injury, creating a whorl of dense, beautiful grain. It was not a flaw. It was a feature. It was the most interesting part of the whole piece. He stood up, letting the wood and the knife fall unheeded into the grass. The new hum inside him, the chord of understanding, was no longer a tentative sound. It was a deep, resonant cello note, a baseline against which a new kind of music could be played. He felt an urge, a familiar creative stirring, but it had a different timbre than the old, anxious need. It was not a frantic desire to impose beauty upon the world, but a quiet, compelling curiosity to enter into a conversation with it.

“I need to cook,” he said, not to Mabli, but to himself, testing the words. They didn't taste of poison or trauma. They tasted of possibility. He turned and walked towards his home, not with the grim purpose of the past few weeks, but with a light, thoughtful tread. Mabli followed, her presence a quiet, steady support. Inside, he did not go to his larder, with its collection of perfect, static ingredients. Instead, he went straight to his hearth. The cold slate still held the reflection of the grey, afternoon light. He knelt before it, and this time, it did not feel like approaching an altar or a tombstone. It felt like greeting an old friend who had been waiting patiently for his return. He took a soft cloth and wiped its surface clean, not with his old, obsessive precision, but with a simple, preparatory care.

“I’m coming with you,” Mabli said, already guessing his next move. Gwyn looked at her and nodded. This would not be a solitary act of creation. It couldn't be. They flew out into the late afternoon, but they did not go to the pristine, untouched places. He led them to the western ridge, to the site of the newly-carved relief channel. The raw earth of the trench was a scar on the green hillside, but the water flowing within it was clear, and the surrounding ground was firm and safe. He landed beside it and began to search. He found what he was looking for at the base of the channel, where the force of the water had exposed the bedrock. He selected a stone, not a river-smooth, perfectly symmetrical one, but a fragment of sandstone, its edges still sharp from the fracture, its surface gritty with a story of pressure and release.

Next, he went to the badger sett. He did not approach the main entrance, which was now a bustling hub of activity, but went to the side, to the place where Bronwen had offered him the burdock root. He found a small, tenacious clump of moss growing on the earth that had been dug out and replaced. It was not the deep, velvety moss of an ancient forest; it was a young, bright green pioneer, its tiny rhizoids already working to bind the disturbed soil together. It was the moss of mending. He took a small piece, a living stitch in the fabric of the land. His final ingredient he found near the old bridge. In the lee of the new groin of heavy stones the pixies had begun to build, a small patch of calm water had formed. In this sheltered spot, a single, brave shoot of watercress grew, its leaves a vibrant, peppery green. It was not a perfect specimen; one of its leaves was torn, a casualty of the turbulent water it had survived. He snipped it carefully, its story of shelter and resilience held within its crisp stem.

Back in his home, the light was turning golden. He lit the hearth. The flame caught with its familiar *whoomph*, but it felt different. It was not the start of a performance, but the kindling of a conversation. He placed the sandstone fragment on the slate. As it heated, it released a dry, mineral scent, the smell of the deep, stable earth. He took the bright green moss of mending and gently bruised it with the handle of his flawed flint knife, releasing its damp, earthy aroma. He didn't make a reduction. He simply laid the bruised moss on the hot stone, where it sizzled softly, its scent mingling with the dry heat of the rock. Finally, he took the single shoot of watercress and laid it beside the moss. Its torn leaf curled slightly in the heat, its peppery scent a sharp, bright counterpoint to the other aromas. Stone, moss, and leaf. Fracture, mending, and survival.

He scraped the heated arrangement onto a simple wooden platter. There was no swirl, no rosette, no garnish. It was a composition of truths. He broke it into two portions, giving one to Mabli. He took a bite. The gritty texture of the heated sandstone, the deep, earthy taste of the moss, and the sharp, vital bite of the watercress. It was a meal that tasted of persistence. It tasted of the pressure that forms a crystal, the wind that strengthens a branch, the darkness that makes the light worth reaching for. It was the taste of the world as it truly was: a beautiful, resilient thing, constantly falling apart and stubbornly, magnificently, holding itself together. He looked at Mabli, who was chewing thoughtfully, her expression a mixture of surprise and a deep, dawning understanding. The low, resonant hum in his chest was steady and warm. He was home. Not just in the hollow of his oak, but in the heart of his own, mended life.
